The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE POPES BVLL GELDED Or AN EDICT Publiſhed by the Duke and State of Venice, againſt the late Bull of Pope Paulus Quintus, the ſixth of May 1606. in the fourth Indiction.
Truly Tranſlated out of the Italian Coppy, as appeareth in this Booke.
LONDON. Printed for Iohn Hardie, dwelling on Saint Peters Hill. 1606.

opener.signed: LEONARDO DONATO by the Grace of God Duke of Venice, &c.
opener.salute: To the moſt Reuerend Patriarkes, Archbiſhops, Biſhops, of all our Dominions of Venice, & to all Vicars Abbots, Priors, Rectors of Pariſh Churches, and other Prelates Eccleſiaſticall. Health.

div.p:
IT hath come to our knowledge that the 17. of Aprill laſt paſt by order of the moſt Holy Father Pope Paule the fift, was publiſhed and affixed in Rome a certaine Bull thundred
out againſt vs, our Senate and Dominion, directed to you, of ſuch Tenor and Contents as therein appeareth. VVhereupon finding our ſelues bound to preſerue in peace and Tranquillitie the State which God hath giuen vs to gouerne: and to maintaine the Authority of a Prince that in temporall affaires acknowledgeth no Superior vnder the diuine Maieſtie. VVe by theſe our publike letters proteſt before God, and to all the world, that we haue not failed to vſe all poſſible meanes to make his Holineſſe capable of our moſt ſtrong and inſoluble Reaſons. Firſt by our Ambaſſador Lieger with his Holineſſe: Then by our letters, reſponſiue to Breiſes written by him; and finally by a ſpeciall Ambaſſador ſent for this verry purpoſe. But finding his holines eares ſhut vnto vs, and ſeeing the foreſaid Bull to haue beene publiſhed againſt the forme of all reaſon, and contrarie to that which the diuine Scriptures, the doctrine of holy Fathers, and the ſacred Canons doe teach vs, in preiudice of the ſecular Authoritie giuen
vs from God, & of the libertie of our State, with diſturbance of the quiet poſſeſſion, which by Gods grace our faith full ſubiects vnder our gouernment hold of their goods, honors, and liues, with vniuerſall & greeuous ſcandall of all. VVe doubt not a whit to hold the foreſaid Bull, not only for vniuſt and vnlawfull, but alſo for anulled and of no value, and ſo without force, fruſtrated, and vnlawfully thundred, De facto nullo Iuris ordine ſeruato. Wherefore we haue reputed it conuenient to vſe againſt the fame ſuch remedies as our Aunceſtors and other Soueraigne Princes haue vſed with Popes, that haue extended the power giuen thē by God for edification, beyond their limites. Eſpecially being perſwaded that by your & other our Loyall ſubiects, and by the whole world it ſhall be ſo held and reputed. Aſſuring our ſelues, that as you haue hitherto, attended to the Cure of ſoules of our faithfull ſubiectes, and to the Diuine ſeruice, which through your diligence flouriſheth in this our ſtate no leſſe thenin
any other ſo you, will hereafter continue in the ſelfe ſame paſtorall care, being it our moſt ſtedfaſt Reſolution to continue in the holy Catholique and Apoſtolike faith and in the obſeruance of the Holy Romain Church; euen as our Predeceſſors from the beginning of the foundation of this Citty till this preſent by the grace of God haue done. And we will that theſe our Letters for the vnderſtanding of all men be affixed in the publike places of this our Citty, and ſo of all other ſubiect to our Dominion, Aſſuring our ſelues that ſo manifeſt a publication will come to the eares of all ſuch as haue had knowledge of the foreſaid Bull; and alſo to the notice of his Holineſſe, whom we beſeech our Lord God to inſpire that he may vnderſtand the Nullitie of his Bull & of other his attempts againſt vs, and that he taking knowledge of the Iuſtice of our cauſe, we may be encouraged to obſerue our Reuerence to the Holy Sea Apoſtolike, of the which we and our forefathers, together with this Commonwealth
haue beene, and will be euer moſt deuoted.

closer.dateline: Giuen at our Ducall Pallace the ſixth of Maye in the fourth Indiction. 1606.

div.p: Imprinted by Rampazotto Printer to the Duke.

opener.signed: Leonardo Donato per gratia di Dio Duce di Venetia, &c.
opener.salute: ALLI Reuerendiſſimi Patriarchi, Arciueſcoui, Veſcoui di tutto il Dommio noſtro di Venetia, & alli Vicarij, Abbati Priori, Rettori, delle Chieſe Parochiali, & altri Prelati Eccleſiaſtici Salute.

div.p:
Evenuto à notitia noſtra, che li xvij. Aprile pro ſſimo paſsato per ordine del Santiſsimo Padre Paulo Papa Quinto è ſtato publicato, & affiſſo in Roma vn'aſſerto Breue fulminato contra Noi & il Senato, & Dominio noſtro, diretto à voi, deltenore, & continenza come in quello. Per il che ritrouandoſi in obligo di conſeruare in quiete, & tranquillitalo Stato datoci da dio in gouerno, & mantenere l'auttorità di Principe, che non ricon oſce nelle coſe temporali alcun ſuperiore ſotto la Diuina Maestà, per queſte noſtre publice littere proteſtiamo innanzi al Signor Dio, & à tutto il. Mondo, che non habbiamo mancato di vſare tutti limodi poſſibili per render la Santità ſua
capace delle validiſsime, & inſolubile ragioni noſtre, Prima per mezzo dell Oratore noſtro reſidē te appreſso la ſua Santità, Poi per lettere noſtre, reſpōſiue alli Breui, ſerittici dalei, Et finalmente per vnoratore eſpreſſo, mandatole à questo effetto: Ma hauendo trouate chiuſe le orrecchie della Santita ſua, & vedendo il Breue ſudetto eſsere publicato contro la forma d'ogni ragione, & contra quello, che le Diuine ſcritture, la dottrina delli Santi Padri, & li Sacri Canonimſegnano, in pregiudicio dell auttorita ſecolare donataci da Dio, & della liberta dello Stato noſtro, con perturbatione della quieta poſſeſsione, che per gratia Diuina ſottol noſtro gouerno li fideli noſtri ſogetti tengono delli beni, honore, & vite loro, & con vniuerſale, & graniſſimo ſcandolo di tutti: non dubittamo punto tenere il ſudetto Breue non ſolo per ingiuſto, & indehito ma anco ra per nullo, & di niſſun valore, & coſi inualido irrito, & fulminato illegitimamente, & de facto nullo iuris ordine ſeruato, che non habbiamo riputato conuenire l'vſar contra quello li remedii, de' quali li noſtri Maggiori, & alteri Principi ſupremi ſi ſono valuti con li Pontefici,
quali nell'adoperare la Poteſta datali da Dio in edificatione, hanno trapaſcati li termini; Maſſime eſsendo certi che da voi, & dalli aliri fideli noſtri ſoggetti, & dal mondo tut to ſara tenuto, & reputato per tale. Aſsicurandoci che voi, ſi come ſino al preſente hauete atteſo alia cura delle anime delli noſtri fideli, & al culto Diuino, il quale per la voſtra diligenza fioriſce in queſto noſtro Stato al pari di qualonque altro coſi all'auuenire continuarete nell'iſteſso vfficio Paſtorale. Eſsendo deliberatione noſtra fermiſsi ma di voler continuare nella Santa Fede Cattolica, & Apoſtolica, & nell'oſseruanza della Santa Chieſa Romana ſi come li Maggiori noſtri dal principio della fondatione di queſta Ci • ta ſin'al preſente per Diuina gratia hanno continuato,

Et queſte noſtre vogliamo, che ad intelligētia di tutti ſiano affiſse nelli luoghi publici d • queſta noſtra Citta & di tutte le altre noſtre fedeli ſuddite al Dominio: Eſsendo certi che vna publicatitione tanto manifeſta andera, allorecchie di tutti quelli ch'hanno auuto cognitione del ſudetto Breue, & peruenire anco a notitia della Santita ſua quale preghiamo Dio noſtro Signore che inſpiri
a conoſcere la nullita del Breue ſuo, et delli altri atti fatti contro di Noi, et conoſciuta la giuſtitia della noſtra cauſa, ciaccreſcalanimo a ſeruare la riuerenza verſo la Santa Sede Apoſtolica, dellaquale Noi, et li noſtri preceſsori inſieme con queſta Repulica ſiamo ſempre ſtati, & ſaremo deuotiſsimi.

closer.dateline: Data nel noſtro Ducal Palazzo a vj di Maggio, nella Indittione Quarta. 1606.
